document.docAuthor: Orr, Michael C., Pitts, James P. & Griswold, Terry
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the bee group Anthophora (Micranthophora) (Hymenoptera: Apidae), with notes on potential conservation concerns and a molecular phylogeny of the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the bee group Anthophora (Micranthophora) (Hymenoptera: Apidae), with notes on potential conservation concerns and a molecular phylogeny of the genus

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Anthaphora albata Cresson, 1876: 211
( lectotype ( Cresson, 1916 ): ♀ ; Denver, Colorado , USA ; coll. Putnam, Jun.; ANSP,

subSubSection.paragraph:
2273).
Anthophora albata Cresson, 1879: 201–211
(implied correction).
Anthophora flexipes Cresson, 1879: 211
( lectotype ( Cresson, 1916 ): ♀ ; Nevada , USA ; coll. Morrison; ANSP, 2275). NEW

SYNONYM.
Anthophora arthuri Cockerell, 1906: 72
( holotype : ♀ ; Maybell, Colorado , USA ; coll. S. Johnson, 1 Aug. 1904 , at Asteraceae

Female similar to male, except: Head: Facial maculations yellow to off-white, sometimes yellow-green. Labrum rim rounded; fully maculated. Clypeal maculation with upward-directed portion of inverted-T thinner ( Fig. 39B ). Scape immaculate. Mesosoma: Legs unmodified in length. Midtibial spur apically pointed; unusually opaque, brown. Basitibial plate circular distally, teardropped overall. Metasoma: T1 covered in appressed setae; T2–T4 usually with apical appressed setal bands undulate, but highly variable in width, sometimes nearly covering terga but sometimes reduced to half; T5 with or without appressed setae. T4 impunctate rim of short length medially, often only slightly visible. Anal fimbria strongly triangular, covering from nearly half to over half of T5 length medially. Pubescence: See Fig. 44B . Leg inner faces brown; hindbasitarsal brush dark brown to blackish; tergal bands usually thicker; anal fimbria dark brown to blackish or light and whitish east of Colorado’s Front Range; sterna light or dark.

Distribution. See Fig. 7 . Present in USA : Utah , California , Idaho , Colorado , Wyoming , Nevada , Oregon , New Mexico , Arizona , Washington , likely Montana ; Mexico : Baja California Norte, possibly Sonora ; possibly Canada : possibly British Columbia . Found throughout much of the West, montane in hotter areas, occupying broader range of environments in colder areas. Ecoregional habitance is as follows, based on 1325 specimen records: 16 ecoregions total: Colorado Plateau shrublands (745=56.2%), Great Basin shrub steppe (259=19.5%), Sierra Nevada Forests (143=10.8%), Snake-Columbia shrub steppe (79=6%), Wyoming Basin shrub steppe (38=2.9%), Great Basin montane forests (13=1%), Colorado Rockies forests (12≤≤1%), California montane chaparral and woodlands (9≤≤1%), Wasatch and Uinta montane forests (9≤≤1%), Mojave Desert (6≤≤1%), California coastal sage and chaparral (3≤≤1%), Eastern Cascades forests (3≤1%), Sierra Juarez and San Pedro Martir pine-oak forest (2≤≤1%), South Central Rockies forests (2≤≤1%), Klamath-Siskiyou forests (1≤≤1%), Western short grasslands (1≤≤1%).
Phenology. Recorded from May–October, heavily dependent on elevation and region, generally flies earlier in warmer regions. Univoltine at higher elevations, potentially bivoltine lower.

Nesting biology. Torchio (1968) described the nesting biology of
A . albata
. This species nests in both horizontal, unconsolidated sand and in vertical sandstone banks. The use of sandstone nests by
A . albata
has been confirmed by the preservation of specimens within nest cells, but whether or not this species excavated these nests is unclear. Although Torchio (1968) claims that this species was witnessed excavating the sandstone nests, he collected both
A . albata
and
A . peritomae
from the site, and the latter is confirmed as a minimally facultative excavator of sandstone nests (
Orr et al . 2016
). Further, he marked many of the nest cells collected from that site as “flexipes or peritomae,” despite no mention of
A . peritomae
anywhere in his paper.

Floral specialization. Likely a specialist on Asteraceae , with great breadth, but possibly generalist with strong Asteraceae preference or, less likely, an eclectic specialist on Asteraceae and
Cleomaceae ( Cane & Sipes 2006 )
. Pure Asteraceae loads were quite common among pollen views (11/15), remaining views also with non-negligible proportions of what was likely Cleomaceae pollen, two nearly purely so and two with <50%. Primary recorded visits by 279 females include: Family Asteraceae (61%), Cleomaceae (10%). 423 total floral records from 14 families include:
Asteraceae
( 97 ♂ 169 ♀ ):

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7. Distribution of
Anthophora albata
. Generated with 1325 specimen records from 313 locations.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Comments. Two names,
A. arthuri
and
A. flexipes
, are here synonymized with
A. albata
. The female type of
A . arthuri
is only notable for its slightly smaller size, lighter setal color in the anal fimbria, and the color of the tibial spurs ( Cockerell 1906 ). All three of these characters vary within some species of A . (
Micranthophora
). Cockerell (1906) himself stated “it may be that this is only a variety of
albata
,” and the authors here agree and formally synonymize
A . arthuri
to the senior synonym
A . albata
. The status of
A . flexipes
is more problematic. The more western
A . flexipes
has been distinguished from the more eastern
A . albata
, in which the terga are covered in appressed setae, including T5, solely on the basis of the reduced amount of appressed pubescence: only apical bands on T1-T4 and none on T5. Numerous exceptions to this have been found in the Sierra Nevada , where some individuals have appressed setae on T5, and the size of the apical bands varies significantly. Further, COI evidence suggests they are the same species (
A . albata
from Colorado versus
A . flexipes
from California have only 1.5% sequence differentiation). Consequently,
A . flexipes
is also formally synonymized with the senior
A . albata
.
